remarks: Documented in Syrian translations of Kalila and Dimna from the 6th century. Early European literary source, see Odo of Cheriton, Fabulae (No. 54). Popu lar as a proverbial phrase.

title: The Cat and the Mouse Converse
description: To escape from being eaten, a mouse tells a cat a tale or has a long dialog with her. Finally the cat announces that she will eat the mouse anyway [K561.1.1].

literature.Danish: Kristensen 1896, Nos. 105–109, Kuhre 1938, No. 16, Holbek 1990, No. 1
literature.Greek: Loukatos 1957, 25 No. 2, cf. No. 3, cf. Megas 1956f. I, 34f.

title: The Wolf Unjustly Accuses the Lamb and Eats Him
description: A lamb is ac cused of muddying water even though it is drinking downstream from the wolf (tiger, hyena) [U31].

literature.South African: Coetzee et al. 1967, Schmidt 1989 II, No. 638.

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 451 No. 155). Popular as a proverbial phrase .

title: A Drunkard’s Promise
description: A drunken mouse challenges a cat to fight. The cat is about to kill him when the mouse reminds the cat that, when the cat was drunk, he had promised the mouse never to kill him. “That was a drunkard’s promise”, says the cat, and kills the mouse. Cf. Type 132.

title: Country Mouse Visits Town Mouse
description: A town mouse is given hospitality by a country mouse but is shocked by his poor food. The town mouse persuades the country mouse to visit her and leads her into the pantry. They are interrupted by a cat or the owner of the house . The country mouse is frightened and prefers her own poverty [J211.2]. Cf. Type 201.

literature.Spanish: Camarena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, Nos. 112, 215, Goldberg 1998, No. J211.2
cf: Chauvin 1892ff. II, 114 No. 85, 185 No. 32, III, 57 No. 17

remarks: Documented by Horace, Sermones (II,6, 79–117), also Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 485f. No. 352). Popular as a proverbial phrase.

title: The Mice Carry the Egg
description: A mouse (rat) lies on her back and holds an egg between her legs. A second mouse pulls her into the cave by her tail.
remarks: Documented by La Fontaine, Fables (X,1).

title: The Mice and the Rooster
description: The mother mouse warns her children about the cat and tells them that the rooster whom they fear is harmless [J132].

title: The Mice Choose Cat as King
description: This miscellaneous type consists of various tales in which mice choose a cat as their king.

title: Pan is Dead (previously King of the Cats Is Dead )
description: A man (dwarf) hears a voice (of a cat) that tells him to announce that a third figure (the god Pan, the king of the cats) is dead. The man does not recognize either the voice or the name of the dead person. When he comes home he tells what happened. When the maid (cat) hears this, she says she has to leave (is now the new king of the cats), goes away, and never comes back [B342]. In some variants a man kills a cat that follows him. Before she dies, the cat tells the man to inform a particular person of her death. When the man comes home and tells what happened, his own cat kills him.

literature.Austrian: Vernaleken 1859, No. 39, Depiny 1932, 35, 39, 40 nos. 37, 58, 65, 67, Haiding 1965, No. 328

remarks: Documented by Plutarch, De defectu oraculorum (17); with cats in the 16th century in the Zimmerische Chronik.

title: The Cat as Sham Holy Man
description: A cat (tom-cat) who pretends to be a holy man (a pilgrim) enlists mice (rats) as disciples. It eats them one by one as they file by or listen to his sermons. In some variants the cat fails to deceive the mice [K815.13, cf. K815.7]. Cf. Types 20D*, 165.
remarks: Documented in the Indian Jātaka (nos. 128, 129). Early European lit erary source, see Odo of Cheriton, Fabulae (No. 15).

title: The Hungry Fox Waits in Vain for the scrotum of the ram to fall off [J2066
description: 1]. Cf. Type 59.
remarks: Documented in the Indian Pañcatantra (II,6).

title: The Bear on the Hay-Wagon
description: A bear enters a horsedrawn vehicle in the forest. The horse starts and the bear is mistaken for the clergy man [J1762.2].

title: The Bear Riding the Horse lets his claws sink into the horse’s flanks
description: When he is caught on a tree and the horse runs on, he is torn in two [J2187].

literature.Spanish: Camarena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, Río Cabrera/Pérez Bautista 1998, Nos. 27, 28

title: See Type 47D.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Lion Frightened by the Horse
description: An old horse meets a lion who asks him if he can press water out of a stone. The horse says no, but he can strike sparks (with his hooves) out of the stone. The lion is very impressed and he tells the wolf (bear) about the horse. The wolf boasts of having eaten many horses. The lion thereupon picks up the wolf to show him the horse and squeezes him to death by mistake. But he thinks the horse’s glance killed the wolf [J2351.4]. Cf. Types 103C*, 125B*.

title: See Type 200C*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: Horse’s Defense against Wolves
description: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) In a fight between a lion and bulls, the lion sets the bulls against each other so he can overcome them [J1022]. Cf. Type 201F*. (2) Horses protect themselves from wolves by putting their foals in the middle of a circle and turning their hindquarters toward their enemies.

literature.Catalan: Neugaard 1993, No. J1022, Goldberg 1998, No. J1022

remarks: Variants with lion and bulls derive from an Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 487 No. 372).

title: See Type 47D.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The First to See the Sunrise
description: A fox and a hog have a contest to see who can be the first to see the sunrise. The fox places himself on a hill facing the east, the hog in a lower place facing the high trees in the west. The sun shines first on the top of the trees and the hog wins. (Sometimes with human actors.) [K52.1].

literature.Portuguese: Oliveira 1900f. II, No. 321, Cardigos (forth coming), No. 1245*B

title: Wolves Climb on Top of One Another (previously Wolves Climb on Top of One Another to Tree )
description: Wolves (tigers) want to punish a man (hog) who has hurt one of them (cut off his tail, poured hot water on him). The man escapes up a tree and the wolves climb on top of one another to reach him. When the man threatens the wolves again, the lowest wolf runs away and all fall down (are killed) [J2133.6]. Cf. Type 1250.

literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 567, Tauscher 1959, No. 45, Thompson/Roberts 1960, Jason 1989

title: Animal Loses His Prey Because His Victim Can Escape by False Plea (previously The Wolf loses his Prey) [K550]
The Wolf (Fox) Seeks Breakfast
description: (Including the previous Type 91A*.) A wolf (fox) threatens to eat various animals (hog, sheep, horse), but they ask for a last favor: One has to baptize his children [K551.8], a second one wants to squeal before the wolf eats him up, so that help comes [K551.3.4] (previously Type 91A*), and one wants to finish his prayer [K551.1] (cf. Type 1199). The wolf stays hungry (is killed).

literature.Portuguese: Soromenho/ Soromenho 1984f. I, Nos. 42, 44–46, 75, Cardigos (forthcoming), Nos. 122, 122A
literature.German: cf. Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 II, No. 86, Hubrich-Messow 2000
literature.Turkish: Eberhard/Boratav 1953, Nos. 11 V, 13 V, Alptekin 1994, Nos. III 30ff., V 92f.
literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 674, Thompson/Roberts 1960, No. 91A*, Jason 1989, No. 122

title: The Rat Persuades the Cat to Wash Her Face before Eating
description: A cat catches a rat (sparrow, squirrel) and is about to eat it. The rat tells the cat that no one eats a meal without having washed his mouth. The cat cleans her mouth and the victim escapes. The cat promises her self to clean her mouth only after a meal [K562].

literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 610, Thom pson/ Roberts 1960, Jason 1989

title: The Sheep Persuades the Wolf to Sing before he eats him
description: The wolf starts to howl (play the flute), so that the dogs come and farmers beat up (chase away) the wolf [K561.2].

literature.Spanish: Camarena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, González Sanz 1996, Goldberg 1998, No. K561.2
cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. M. 104, M. 245, M. 253, M. 266, cf. No. H. 99

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 440f. No. 97).

title: Caught Animal Promises Captor Better Prey (previously “Let me Catch you Better Game” )
description: A captured hare (sheep, rooster, black bird, fox) pretends to help a wolf (fox, lion) and promises a more desirable victim. Thus the hare escapes [K553.1]. Cf. Type 106*.

title: Wait for the Fat Goat
description: Three goats (billy goats) have to pass a bridge where a troll keeps guard, or they meet a wolf who wants to eat them. He lets the two small ones pass in order to get the biggest one, who throws him into the river [K553.2].

title: “Wait till I am Fat Enough
description: ” A captured animal (hog, sheep, dog) persuades his captor (wolf) to wait until he is fat enough to eat. Thus he escapes [K553].

literature.Portuguese: Vasconcellos/Soro menho et al. 1963f. I, Nos. 33, 35, Cardigos (forthcoming)
cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. H. 18, M. 307, M

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 447 No. 134).

title: “Wash Me” (“Soak Me”) before Eating
description: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A wolf (jackal, fox) wants to eat a piglet (crabs and fish). The sow persuades the wolf that she has to wash the piglet first, and pulls the wolf into the water. (2) A turtle explains to a jackal that he has to be soaked in water in order to soften his shell. Thus he escapes [K553.5].

title: “Wait until I Get Dry
description: ” A monkey is pulled from mud by a tiger who wants to eat him. He asks the tiger to be allowed to dry in sun before being eaten. Thus he escapes [K551.12].

literature.Spanish: Camarena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, Río Cabrera/Pérez Bautista 1998, Nos. 33, 34

remarks: Early literary source in a Spanish text in the exempla collection of Odo of Cheriton (El libro de los gatos , No. 56).

title: See Type 47B.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: Other Tricks to Escape being Eaten
description: (Including the previous Types 69** and 87B*.) This miscellaneous type consists of various tales about other tricks of animals to escape being eaten by the wolf (fox, etc.).
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 593ff. No. 699). Also documented in the middle of the 12th century in the Ysengrimus (II,159–688), then in the 13th century in the Roman de Renart (XX,1–94).

title: The Wolf and the Kids
description: A wolf comes while a mother goat is away, hoping to eat her kids (kid). When they do not open the door, the wolf changes his voice [K1832, K311.3] and colors his paws with flour [K1839.1]. The children believe that it is their mother and they open the door. The wolf eats the kids (all except one). The youngest kid hides in a clock. The mother returns and takes revenge on the wolf. She finds him asleep, cuts her children out of his belly [F913], and fills it with stones [Q426]. Or, she challenges him to a fight, which she wins. Or, she invites him to her house where he falls into a pit of hot coals. Cf. Types 333, 705B, 2028. In older variants the kid obeys his mother and does not open the door [J144].

literature.German: Tomkowiak 1993, 239, Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 I, No. 5, Hubrich-Messow 2000
cf: cf. Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. M. 184, not-H. 121

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 529 No. 572), then documented in the 12th century by Marie de France, Ésope (No. 89) and ca. 1350 by Ulrich Boner, Edelstein (No. 33).

title: The Fox Buys a Foal and Leaves It at Home
description: A fox cheats some herdsmen out of a foal which he raises. One day when the fox is not at home a wolf changes his voice. The foal lets the wolf into the house and is eaten. The fox takes revenge on the wolf. Cf. Type 123.

title: Wolf in Sheep’s Clothing Gains Admission to the Fold
description: This miscellaneous type consists of various tales, in which a wolf (fox) disguises himself as a sheep (occasionally a shepherd) in order to join the herd and eat the sheep [K828.1, K934]. Either he succeeds, or he is dis covered and beaten (killed). Cf. Types 37, 214B.
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 513 No. 451). Documented in the Middle Ages by Odo of Cheriton, Liber parabolarum (No. 51). Popular as a proverbial phrase.

title: Blowing the House In [Z81]
description: (Including the previous Type 124A*.) A goose builds a house of feathers, a hog one of stone. A wolf (bear) blows the goose’s house down and eats her. He cannot blow down the hog’s house. He tries to lure the hog but the hog outwits him: e.g. the wolf suggests they steal apples together (go to the market) but the hog goes earlier so that the wolf cannot eat him. Finally the wolf tries to get into the house through the chimney. He is burned or scald ed with boiling water [J2133.7, cf. K891.1.]. Cf. Type 43. Or, three pigs build one house of straw, one of sticks, and one of iron. The wolf destroys the first two houses and eats the pigs but the third pig is able to outwit him. (Previously Type 124A*.)

title: See Type 124.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Wolf Flees from the Wolf-Head
description: Domestic animals (sheep, donkey) find a sack and the head (bones) of a dangerous animal (wolf, tiger). They meet another wolf and make him believe that they have killed one of his kind. The wolf flees in terror [K1715.3]. Cf. Types 126, 1149.
remarks: Documented in the middle of the 12th century in the Ysengrimus (IV, V,1–810).

title: Contest between Donkey and Lion (previously Ass Overawes Lion)
description: (Including the previous Types 125C* and 125D*.) This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A donkey brags to a lion about his abilities and is challenged to press water out of a piece of wood (offers to beat water from the ground with his hoof). When the donkey urinates from the effort, the lion takes him for the stronger animal. Cf. Type 118. (2) A lion pulls down the top of a tree and challenges a donkey to do the same thing. The donkey is thrown into a bush where he falls on a rabbit and kills it. After that the donkey boasts about his abili ties (previously Type 125C*). Cf. Type 1051 (with human actors). (3) A donkey impresses a lion by catching a fish in his ear while he takes a bath in the river (previously Type 125D*). Cf. Type 103C*.

literature.Kurdish: Wentzel 1978, No. 41, cf. Džalila et al. 1989, No. 183

title: See Type 125B*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: See Type 125B*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Sheep Chases the Wolf
description: A wolf (tiger) wants to eat a sheep (goat). The sheep pretends to eat wolves and chases the wolf away [K1715]. Cf. Type 1149.

title: The Frightened Wolves
description: A he-goat, a cat and a ram run away from their owners. When they meet some wolves and a bear, they take refuge in a tree. While they are in the tree, the wolves threaten to eat them. The he-goat falls in fright on a wolf and injures him with his horns. The wolves run away. Cf. Type 130, 1154.

title: See Type 122M*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Wolf Induces the Goat to Come down from a Cliff and Devours It
description: In some variants the goat refuses to come [K815, K2061.4]. Cf. Type 242.

literature.Portuguese: Vasconcellos/Soromenho et al. 1963f. I, No. 53, Cardigos (forth coming)

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 451 No. 157).

title: The Goat Eats in the Garden and is Caught
description: The fox says, “If your sense were as long as your beard, you would have looked for an exit as well as an entrance”. [J2136.3].

title: Two Sheep Kill a Fox who licked up the blood they spilled in a fight [J624
remarks: Documented in the Arabian version of Kalila and Dimna .

title: Sheep Licks Her New-Born Lamb
description: When a wolf watches this he says, “This is not fair. If I were to do that they would say I was eating it.” [J1909.5]. Cf. Type 1837*.
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 457 No. 190).

title: The Animals in Night Quarters
description: (Bremen Town Musicians.) Donkey, dog, cat and rooster are ill-treated by their owners because they are too old to work. They run away [B296] and find a lonely house in the forest [N776]. Thieves come and begin to divide their money. The four animals climb on one another ’s backs and cry all at once [K335. 1.4]. The thieves (robbers) are frightened and run away, leaving the money there. When the thieves try to come back the animals hide in various parts of the house and attack them with their characteristic powers [K1161]. The four animals drive the thieves away and live happily ever after. Cf. Type 210.

literature.German: Brunner/Wachinger 1986ff. XI, No. 2S3581, Tomkowiak 1993, 239f., Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 I, No. 27, Hubrich-Messow 2000, Berger 2001
literature.Turkish: Eberhard/Boratav 1953, No. 11, Alptekin 1994, Nos. III 58, V 90

title: Animals Build Themselves a House
description: Domestic animals (ox, rooster, ram, pig) escape from their owner and want to build a house. In some variants only one of them builds a house for the winter and the others think they do not need one. The animal with the house nevertheless must give them shelter. Cf. Types 43, 80, and 81.

title: Fleeing Animals Threatened with Death (previously Animals in Flight after Threatened Death)
description: Domestic animals (goat, ram, cat, donkey, dog, rooster) flee from their home. In the night a pack of wolves wants to eat them, but they defend themselves successfully. Cf. Types 130.

title: Animals in Company of a Man
description: Donkey, goat, dog and cat look for a new home. They find an old woman (man) and promise to work for her. In some variants they cheat the old person, and in other variants they help her.

title: Animals Warm Themselves
description: Domestic animals flee because they are treated badly. To start a fire, the cat advises the goat to wind some birch bark around his head like horns and to have a fight with the ram. The bark begins to burn. A bear warms himself at the fire. When they are attacked by wolves, they defend themselves success fully.

title: The Tiger as False Friend to the Cow
description: A tiger and a cow become friends and both bear offspring. The tiger drinks water downstream from the cow, decides her flesh would be sweet, and kills and de vours her. The calf flees. The cub of the tiger is ashamed of its mother and accompanies the calf on adventures [J427]. Cf. Type 59*.

title: The Goat Admires His Horns in the Water, and says to himself that he does not have to fear the wolf
description: The wolf stands behind him and asks what he was saying. The goat answers, “Nothing – people who have drunk too much say foolish things”. [K1775]. Cf. Type 111A*.

cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, No. M. 190, cf. S. 146

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 588f. No. 695).

title: The Goat Carries the Snake over a Stream
description: A goat (turtle, fox) carries a snake (scorpion, crocodile) over a river. When they have crossed it, the snake kills the goat: Nature always asserts itself [U124]. In some variants the goat kills the snake [K952.1]. Cf. Types 155, 279*.
remarks: Documented e.g. in Turk and Persian versions of Kalila and Dimna , in the Indian Pañcatantra and by Odo of Cheriton, Liber parabolarum (No. 18).

title: The Mouse Makes a Boat of a Bread-Crust
description: She takes other ani mals and birds into the boat and it capsizes. The animals quarrel [B295.1].

literature.Portuguese: Vasconcellos/Soromenho et al. 1963f. I, No. 80, Cardigos (forthcoming)

title: The Fox Stumbles over a Violin
description: When he is chased by dogs, a fox stumbles over a violin and says, “What a fine opportunity to dance if I had the time!” [J864.1].

literature.Spanish: Camarena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, Río Cabrera/Pérez Bautista 1998, No. 41

title: The Wolf Surprises the Pig in an Apple Tree
description: A wolf sees a pig in an apple tree. He promises not to eat the pig if the pig will throw him one his hams. The pig throws down a piece of thorny wood instead, which cuts the wolf ’s throat [K1043]. Cf. Type 74C*.

title: Confession of Animals
description: A cat says she will confess her sins. Other animals (hare, wolf, fox) want to do the same and accompany her. At a ditch the cat says, “He who can cross it safely shall be without sin”. [M114]. Only the cat crosses the ditch; the other animals fall in and the cat laughs at them.

title: The Filthy Hog and the Clean Fish
description: A fish laughs at a hog because it is so filthy. The hog says to the fish, “People will spit when they eat you, whereas in my case all will lick their fingers”. Cf. Type 283D*.
remarks: Aesopic fable of Babrios (Babrius/Perry 1965, No. 217).

title: The Three Teachings of the Bird (previously Advice of the Fox )
description: In return for his freedom, a bird (fox) gives a man three pieces of advice: first, “never try to reach the unattainable” [J21.14], second “Do not regret a thing that is past” [J21.12], and third, “Never believe what is beyond belief” [J21.13]. The bird tells him a lie. The man regrets having freed the bird, and the bird says that the man learned nothing from the advice [K604]. In some (parodistic) variants a fox promises three pieces of advice to a ferryman. As they cross the river the fox offers two trivial aphorisms. When they reach the bank, the fox, as the third piece of advice, tells the ferryman that he will never get rich if he transports everyone so cheaply.

literature.Spanish: Camarena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, Goldberg 1998, Nos. J21.12, J21.13, J21.14
literature.Catalan: Neugaard 1993, Nos. J21.12, J21.13, J21.14, K604, cf. Oriol/Pujol 2003
literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 720, cf. No. 721, Thompson/Roberts 1960, Jason 1989

remarks: Aesopic fable (Babrius/Perry 1965, No. 53). Also documented in Barlaam and Josaphat.

title: The Frog’s Counsels
description: (Including the previous Type 278C*.) A farmer agrees to take in a frog for the winter, and in return it gives him three trite counsels [K604]. The frog is beaten and therefore becomes hunchbacked [A2356. 2.1]. (Previously Type 278C*.)

title: A Man Teaches a Wild Animal to Play the Fiddle (previously The Man Teaches Bears to Play the Fiddle )
description: A wild animal (bear, wolf) sees a man playing the fiddle in the forest, or a man is locked up with a dangerous animal (lion, tiger, wolf). He plays on his fiddle for the animal, who asks to learn how to play the instrument. The man says he must cut his claws and catches the animal’s paws in a cleft tree [K1111.0.1]. Similarly the man tricks other animals. After the animals get free, they try in vain to take revenge. Cf. Types 38, 168, and 1159.

title: The Lion in Love
description: A lion in love asks to marry the daughter of a farmer, who tells him he must give up his teeth and his claws. He allows them to be cut, but then he is helpless against the farmer ’s abuse [J642.1].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 448 No. 140).

title: The Plowman and the Animals (previously The Man Paints the Bear)
description: (Including the previous Type 152B*.) A plowman punishes animals that disturb him in his work. He burns a bear (wolf) with red-hot iron [K1013.3], tears off the legs of a crow (magpie) and pricks a gadfly with a blade of grass. Cf. Types 8, 153. The animals then watch the man with his girlfriend and interpret his behavior accordingly. The bear says: “He is drawing a pattern on her sides”. The crow says, “He is twisting her leg”. The gadfly says, “He is sticking a stalk of grass into her backside”. [J2211]. (Prev iously Type 152B*.)

title: The Wife Scalds the Wolf
description: At a signal from her husband, a wife scalds a wolf with boiling water. The next day, the man is attacked by the wolf. He escapes by shouting, “Pour, Catherine!” The wolf flees.

title: See Type 152.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Gelding of the Bear and the Fetching of Salve
description: A man tells a bear that the horse is strong because it is gelded. The bear has the man geld him to make him strong [K1012.1]. The next day the bear wants to geld the man. The man substi tutes his wife [K241] to pretend they have been already cas trated. The bear is shocked by the “wound” of the woman and goes for salve. A fox guards the woman, but she drives him away with her farts. Cf. Type 1133.
remarks: Documented in the Indian Kathāsaritsāgara.

title: The Fox and His Members (previously “Bear-food” )
description: (Including the previous Type 160B*.) A man in anger calls his horse “bear-food”. A bear comes and threatens to eat the horse [C25]. A fox agrees to help the man against the bear in return for geese. The fox goes into the forest and imitates the barking of dogs. The bear is intimidated and killed. The man pretends to go for the geese but instead brings dogs back in his bag [K235]. The dogs chase the fox to his hole. Here the fox asks his feet, eyes, ears, and tail how they helped him in his flight. His tail admits that it did not help. As a punishment the fox sticks out his tail and is attacked by dogs [J2351.1]. In some variants a hare asks his members about their help in his flight [U242.1]. (Previously Type 160B*.)

literature.Laotian: Lindell et al. 1977ff. I, 39ff., II, 50ff., cf. III, 23ff.

remarks: Early version in Petrus Alfonsus, Disciplina clericalis (No. 23). Also documented ca. 1200 in the Roman de Renart (IX,1–2212). Often manifested in single episodes, esp. the last one.

title: The Ungrateful Snake Returned to Captivity
description: A man rescues a snake (wolf, bear, tiger) from a trap. In return the snake seeks to kill the rescuer [W154.2.1]. Other animals are asked if a good deed should be repayed with a bad one. The fox, as judge, asks the snake to show how it was trapped. The snake is tricked into captivity [J1172.3]. Cf. Types 331, 926A. In some variants a man warms a cold snake. The ungrateful snake bites the man and he dies.

literature.French: Delarue/Tenèze 1964ff. III, Cifarelli 1993, No. 180, cf. No. 249
literature.Spanish: Camarena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, Goldberg 1998, Nos. J1172.3, W154.2.1
literature.Portuguese: Vasconcellos/Soromenho et al. 1963f. I, Nos. 65–67, Cardigos (forthcoming)
literature.German: Moser-Rath 1964, No. 126, Tomkowiak 1993, 228, cf. 226, Kooi/Schuster 1994, No. 239, Hubrich-Messow 2000
literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, Nos. 1150, 1153, 2255, cf. Nos. 303, 1151, Tauscher 1959, No. 170, Thompson/Roberts 1960, Jason 1989
literature.Egyptian: Nowak 1969, No. 246, El-Shamy 1995 I, No. J1172.3.2
literature.Moroccan: Nowak 1969, No. 43, El-Shamy 1995 I, No. J1172.3.2
literature.South African: Coetzee et al. 1967, Schmidt 1989 II, No. 590, Klipple 1992
cf: Chauvin 1892ff. II, 119 No. 5, 120 No. 109, VI, 197f. No. 370, VIII, 120 No. 104, IX, 18 No. 4

remarks: Documented in the 12the century by Petrus Alfonsus, Disciplina cleri calis (No. 5). Parts are Aesopic (Perry 1965, 558ff. No. 640, 560f. 640a).

title: Androcles and the Lion (previously Thorn Removed from Lion’s Paw [Androcles and the Lion] )
description: (Including the previous Type 156A*.) A shepherd pulls a thorn out of a lion’s paw. When the shepherd is thrown as a punishment into a pit of lions, the lion recognises him and licks his hand instead of tearing him to pieces. The emperor releases both [B381]. Or, a bone is removed from an animal’s (wolf, tiger, bear) throat, and later the animal shows gratitude to the rescuer [B382]. (Pre viously Type 156A*.) Cf. Type 76.

literature.South African: Coetzee et al. 1967, Schmidt 1989 II, No. 1690.

remarks: Documented by Aulus Gellius, Noctes Atticae (V,14).

title: The Faith of the Lion
description: A man rescues a lion (often from a struggle with a dragon) and out of gratitude it follows the man for his whole life, even to his grave [B301.8].

literature.Dutch: Sinninghe 1943, 17 No. 74, Schippers 1995, No. 208, Kooi 2003, No. 28

remarks: Medieval legend of Henry the Lion.

title: See Type 156.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Grateful Snake (previously Woman as Snake’s Midwife)
description: (Includ ing the previous Type 738*.) This miscellaneous type com prises various tales dealing with a person (man, woman) who helps a snake (e.g. in a battle or to give birth). The snake rewards the person (with gold or money). Cf. Types 285A, 476*, and 476**.

literature.Estonian: Aarne 1918, No. 738*, Loorits 1959, No. 140, Kippar 1986, No. 156B*
literature.Jewish: Jason 1965, No. 738*, Jason 1975, No. 738*, Noy 1976, Jason 1988a, No. 738*

title: The Boy and the Bear in Pit
description: A boy falls into a pit on top of a bear, and helps him to get out of the pit. The bear helps the boy and shows him where to find money. Cf. Types 160, 168.

title: Animals Learn to Fear Men (previously Learning to Fear Men )
description: A wolf (lion, bear) boasts about being stronger than a man. The fox wants to convince him that men are dangerous. They see a boy, and the fox explains that he will be a man later. When they meet an old man, the fox says this was a man but is no longer one. Then they see an armed hunter. The wolf approaches, but the man shots and stabs him with a sabre. Later the wolf tells the fox he could have defeated the man if he did not spit fire and attack him with a sharp rib [J17, J32].

literature.Spanish: Cama rena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, González Sanz 1996, Goldberg 1998, No. J17
literature.German: Tomkowiak 1993, 223, Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 II, No. 72, Hubrich-Messow 2000
literature.South African: Coetzee et al. 1967, Schmidt 1989 II, No. 646.

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 484 No. 340). Documented by Hans Sachs 1551 (Der leb mit dem monthier).

title: The Lion Searches for Man
description: A young lion, warned by his parents to shun man [J22.1], asks other large animals if they are man. They answer that they are only the ill-treated servants of men. He meets a man and is scornful of him, but the man tricks him into entering a cage and leaves him to starve. Or, the man tricks the lion into placing his claws in a cleft of a tree where he is trapped [K1111]. Cf. Types 38, 151.

literature.Bulgarian: Nicoloff 1979, Nos. 4, 5, Parpulova/Dobreva 1982, 44f., cf. BFP, No. *157B

remarks: Documented in ancient Egypt (Jason/Kempinski 1981, 23).

title: The Sparrow and His Sons
description: A sparrow whose children were lost meets them again and asks how they survived. Three of them tell where they lived, and the sparrow praises them. The fourth lives in a church and the old sparrow admires his wise decision [J13].
remarks: Documented in 1563 in a sermon of Johannes Mathesius (Elschen broich 1990 I, 161ff.), cf. Psalm 84,4–5.

title: Hiding from Men
description: The animals want to hide themselves from men. The wild beasts hide in the forest, the birds in the air, the fish in the water. However, man catches them all with his gun, his noose and his fishing-rod.

literature.Portuguese: Vasconcellos/Soromenho et al. 1963f. I, No. 39, Soromenho/Soromenho 1984f. I, No. 73, Cardigos (forthcoming).

title: The Wild Animals on the Sleigh
description: Other animals ask the fox for a ride on his sleigh, which breaks. To repair it, the animals bring unsatis factory material from the forest [B831]. When the fox goes for good material they eat the horse and build a dummy to replace it.

title: Captured Wild Animals Ransom Themselves
description: An old couple spread pitch on a straw calf. One after another, a bear, a wolf, a fox, and a hare touch the calf and stick to it. In return for not being slaughtered, they promise to bring cows, horses, geese and cabbage. Thus the animals ransom themselves and the old people get rich [B278]. Cf. Type 175.

cf: Chauvin 1892ff. VI, 147 No. 304, VIII 148 No. 146, not. 1

title: Animals Warm Selves at Charcoal Burner ’s Fire
description: They are sent after food for dinner. Each of them brings some back, but the charcoal burner drives them away or kills them. Cf. Type 130.

literature.Portuguese: Coelho 1985, Nos. 7, 9, Soromenho/Soromenho 1984f. I, No. 81, Cardigos (forthcoming).

title: Enmity of Lion and Man
description: A lion (bear) helps a man with his work. The man praises his virtues but criticises the bad smell of his mouth. The lion forces the man to strike him on his head with an axe. After a year, the man and the lion meet again. The lion says that his wound is healed but it stills hurts, and devours the man [W185.6]. Cf. Type 285A. In some variants the man ’s wife complains about the lion. The lion overhears this and forces the man to wound him.

title: The Lion and the Statue
description: In order to demonstrate the superiority of humans over animals, a man shows a lion a statue of a conquered lion. The lion replies that if a lion had made the statue, it would have looked different [J1454].
remarks: Documented by Straparola, Piacevoli notti (III,4).

title: Grateful Animals, Ungrateful Man [W154
description: 8]. A traveler saves a tiger (lion, crow), a monkey (bear), a snake, and a man (jeweler) from a pit (from a tree trunk floating in a flood). The animals give their rescuer a reward or promise to help him later. One animal gives him stolen jewels [B361]. The man also promises to reward the rescuer but later he denies it. He accuses the rescuer before the king of having stolen the jewels. The rescuer is to be punished. The snake saves him by biting the king’s child and then showing the rescuer the proper re medy [B522.1, B522.2, B512]. (Cf. Type 101.) The traveler is freed and the jeweler is punished. Often the traveler is warned not to rescue the man.

literature.Spanish: Childers 1977, No. B361, Goldberg 1998, Nos. B361, W154.8
literature.Catalan: Karlinger/ Pögl 1989, No. 44, Neugaard 1993, No. W154.8
literature.German: Bechstein/Uther 1997 I, No. 72, Meier 1852, No. 14, Peuckert 1932, No. 22, Moser-Rath 1964, No. 125
literature.Macedonian: Vroclavski 1979f. II, No. 3, Čepenkov/Penušliski 1989 I, No. 41, cf. No. 44
literature.West African: ZfVk. 4 (1894) 65ff., Barker/ Sinclair 1917, No. 32, Bascom 1975, No. 50

remarks: Documented as a Buddhistic legend in the third century.

title: See Type 168.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: See Type 1897.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: See Type 154.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Farmer Betrays the Fox by Pointing
description: A farmer hides a fox from the hunters in a basket, and promises not to betray him. When the hunters come, he says, “The fox just went over the hill”, but he points to the basket. The hunters do not see this. When the farmer asks the fox to thank him, the fox answers that he would have thanked him if gestures and words had agreed with each other [K2315].

literature.Spanish: Camarena/Che valier 1995ff. I, Goldberg 1998, No. K2315
literature.Serbian: Karadžić 1937, 281 No. 15, cf. Vrčević 1868f. I, No. 373, cf. Eschker 1992, No. 62

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 425 No. 22).

title: The Bear with the Wooden Leg
description: (Including the previous Type 163B*.) A poor old man cuts off a sleeping bear ’s leg with an axe. His wife cooks the leg and spins the fur into yarn. The bear makes himself a leg from linden wood. At night he comes to the house and eats the old man. Or, the bear comes to the house and sings about what was done to him, “All the people are asleep; so are the little birds. Only one old woman is awake, and she spins my wool and boils my flesh.” (Previously Type 163B*.)

title: See Type 485B*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Master Looks More Closely than the Farmhand
description: A stag hides from hunters in a stable, but the cows warn him that he would be more secure in the forest. The farmhand does not notice him, but the master finds him and kills him [J1032, cf. J582.1].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 521 No. 492). Also a proverb documented by Pliny, Naturalis historia (XXII,43).

title: See Type 169*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Wolf Steals and Eats One Sheep, then two, and finally the whole herd and the shepherd
description: The wolf is killed. Cf. Type 2028.

title: The Singing Wolf
description: By his singing (threats or compliments) the wolf compels an old man to surrender his cattle, his children and grandchildren, and finally his wife. In the end the wolf eats the man [Z33. 4.2]. Cf. Type 100.

title: See Type 1586.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: See Type 161A*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: See Type 169*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: “Fish, Not Flesh” (previously The Wolf in the Company of Saints )
description: The wolf promises to give up eating flesh. When he finds a pig in a puddle, he says, “It’s fish, not flesh”, and eats it up. Or, the wolf promises to give up killing animals and wants to be a saint. On his way to the desert he wrings the neck of a gander. He excuses himself, saying: “He should not have hissed at a saint”. [K2055.1, cf. U236]. Cf. Types 20D*, 113B.

title: See Type 169*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Wolf Punished by being Married
description: The wolf is condemned to the most severe punishment. He is forced to get married [K583]. Cf. Type 1516*. In some variants the wolf must take two wives.

literature.Dutch: Overbeke/Dekker et al. 1991, No. 1472, Hogenelst 1997 II, No. 270

remarks: Anecdote of the 16th/17th centuries, e.g. Johannes Hulsbusch, Sylva sermonum iucundissimorum (1568, 290), and Nicolas de Troyes (No. 71).

title: The Wolf Puts His Tail through the Window of the stable and alarms the sheep
description: The farmer snatches at the tail and tears it off.

title: The Wolf Tries to Get Horses (previously Wolf and Horses)
description: (Including the previous Types 166B1*–166B3*.) In the night a wolf comes near the horses. He plunges into the river and then shakes near the fire to exstinguish it (previously Type 166B2*) or he wallows in the mud to splash it into the eyes of the horses (previously Type 166B 3*). A sleeping driver awakes, seizes the wolf ’s tail and tears it off (pre viously Type 166B1*).

literature.Catalan: Oriol/ Pujol 2003. 166B1*–166B 3* See Type 166B*. 166B4* See Type 1910.

title: See Types 1889ff.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Musician in the Wolf Trap
description: (Including the previous Type 160A.) A violinist falls into a wolf ’s hole (sometimes together with a bear). There he encounters a wolf already trapped, and saves himself by playing music [K551.3.1] until someone (sometimes the bear) helps him out of the hole. The wolf is killed [B848.1]. Cf. Types 151, 1652.

title: The Old Woman and the Wolf Fall into the Pit Together
description: The old woman urges the wolf and other animals to sit still. She is rescued by a hunter who either kills the animals or saves them [K735].

title: Miscellaneous Tales of Wolves and Men
description: (Including the previous Types 156*, 157***, 162*, 164A*, 165A*, 169A*–169F*, 169J*, and 169L*.) Three main themes can be distinguished: (1) Tales of wolves that do not attack the people they meet. (2) Tales of wolves that harm or want to harm people. (3) Tales of wolves that are punished by people.

title: See Type 87A*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: See Type 1229.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: See Type 169*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Man Drives with a Tub and Little Pigs
description: Wolves attack a man. He pulls a tub over himself and the little pigs. The wolves put their paws under the tub and the man splits them with a knife. Cf. Type 179B*.

title: See Type 169*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Fox Eats His Fellow-Lodgers
description: A fox who has a shoe spends the night in a house with a rooster. The fox destroys the shoe and blames the rooster, which he demands as reparation. The next night, in another house, the fox eats the rooster, and in the morning he accuses a sheep of having eaten it. He demands the sheep. In the next house he blames the ox for having eaten the sheep, etc. [K443.7]. Cf. Type 1655.

literature.Kurdish: Džalila et al. 1989, No. 188, cf. No. 168

title: See Type 2034F.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Bear Plays with the Boar ’s Young
description: A boar pursues him. The bear climbs up a tree, but the branch breaks and the bear falls down on the boar. They fight each other and the bear is killed.

title: See Type 179*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: Human and Animal Life Spans are Readjusted (previously Men and Animals Readjust Span of Life)
description: (Including the previous Type 828.) God (Zeus) originally gives 30 years to all animals and humans. Donkey, dog and monkey refuse some of their years because of their sufferings. Man wants to have more years and takes them from the animals. Therefore in the middle of their lives people must do the hard work of a donkey, then they bark like old dogs, and at last they are foolish like monkeys [A1321]. (Previously Type 828.)

literature.German: Jahn 1890, 42ff., Neumann 1968b, 184f., Uther 1990a, No. 62, Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 III, No. 176

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 442 No. 105).

title: The Tarbaby and the Rabbit
description: A cunning rabbit (hare, fox, jackal) steals fruit from a garden (field). A figure spread with tar, wax or glue is set out to trap the thief. The rabbit tries to make the tarbaby talk and finally becomes so angry that he strikes it. He sticks to the tarbaby and is captured [K741]. The rabbit is punished [K581.2] or escapes. Cf. Type 159.

literature.Chilean: Hansen 1957, Pino Saa vedra 1960ff. II, No. 92, III, Nos. 241, 299
literature.South African: Coetzee et al. 1967, Schmidt 1989 II, No. 517, Klipple 1992

title: The Thief and the Tiger
description: A tiger overhears a person saying that he fears something worse than the tiger. The word is unknown to the tiger (dripping of rain, sweet, twilight). Thinking it must be a terrible thing, the tiger hides (sometimes among sheep) and is found by a drunken man (thief) who mistakes him for his horse. He rides off on the tiger [J2132.4, cf. N691.1.2] (steals it because it seems to be a very big sheep [N392]). The tiger thinks the man must be the terrible thing he has heard about and meekly submits. In the morning the man sees his mistake and flees. Cf. Type 1692.

literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 965, Thompson/Roberts 1960, Jason 1989, Blackburn 2001, No. 45

remarks: Documented in Indian Pañcatantra (V,10).

title: The Faithful Animal Rashly Killed. See Types 178A–178C, 916.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Innocent Dog (previously Llewellyn and His Dog )
description: A dog (cat, mouse) saves his master ’s child from a snake. When the master sees the dog’s bloody mouth, he thinks the dog has eaten the child and kills it. Later on he finds the dead snake and realizes his mistake [B331.2, B331.2.1].

literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 100, Tauscher 1959, No. 42, Thompson/ Roberts 1960

remarks: Documented in the Indian Tantrākhyāyika (V).

title: The Faithful Dog as Security for a Debt
description: A poor man leaves his dog with a wealthy man as security for a large loan [B579.6]. The dog helps the wealthy man by retrieving stolen goods and driving off thieves. The grateful man sends the dog back to its owner with a letter saying the debt is cancelled. The owner, thinking the dog has run away, kills it [B331.2.2] before he finds the letter.

title: The Thirsty King Kills His Faithful Falcon
description: A king who is out hunting is about to drink a cup of water. His falcon (horse) knocks the cup from his hand. The enraged king kills the falcon. Then he finds out that the cup was full of poison from a snake [B331.1.1].

title: What the Bear Whispered in His Ear
description: A traveler and his guide (two friends) go through a forest in which they meet a dangerous bear. The guide climbs a tree and leaves the traveler at the mercy of the bear. The traveler feigns death and the bear sniffs at him and leaves. The guide wants to know what the bear said to him. The traveler answers, “He said, never trust a coward like you”. [J1488].

literature.Spanish: Cama rena/Chevalier 1995ff. I, González Sanz 1996, Goldberg 1998, No. J1488

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 432 No. 65).

title: Tales about Men and Bears (previously Men and Bear – miscel laneous)
description: (Including the previous Type 171B*.) This miscellaneous type consists of various tales in which the bear is generally hurt (killed).

title: The Bear Pursues the Man (previously The Bear Pursues the Man who Hides in a Bush )
description: A bear pursues a man who hides in a bush. When the bear puts his paws around the bush, the man rips open the bear ’s belly.

title: Man and Bear Hold Each Other Around a Tree
description: A man and a bear take hold of each other around a tree and will not let go. Another man hurries home for help, but does not come back for a long time. When he comes at last, his comrade, who is holding the bear ’s paws, makes him to take his place and goes away. He also stays away for a long time, to take revenge for his friend’s thoughtlessness.

title: An Old Man Carrying a Kneading Trough
description: A man goes through the forest, lies down to rest, and draws a trough over himself. A hare, a wolf, a fox, and a bear come and admire the fine little table. All of them bring something to eat: a cabbage, a lamb, a goose, some honey. Then the man under the table moves, the animals run away and the man gets all their food. Cf. Type 169K*.

title: The Rebounding Bow
description: A hunter who has killed several animals is bitten by a snake. A jackal comes by and nibbles at the hunter ’s bowstring. He is killed when the bow rebounds [J514.2].
remarks: Documented in the Arabian version of Kalila and Dimna and in the 13th century by John of Capua (IV,5).

title: The Man Tells the Leopard’s Secret (previously The Man Tells the Tiger ’s Secret )
description: A lizard and leopard (tiger) play hide and seek. The lizard fastens himself (a crab) onto the leopard’s tail or coats himself with mud so that the leopard cannot grab him. A man witnesses their contest. The leopard is ashamed [J411.10] and threatens him unless he maintains silence. The man betrays the secret and the leopard carries him off. The man escapes by making a noise so that the leopard thinks that the lizard is coming [K1715.5], or by saying he has eggs from which lizards will soon hatch.

literature.Indian: Bød ker 1957a, Nos. 590–593, cf. Nos. 491–493, Thompson/Roberts 1960

title: The Helpful Animal and the Snake
description: The helpful animal sees a snake bite his master. He catches a crow, who is the snake’s confederate, and forces the snake to revive his master by sucking out the poison [B478, B511.1.3].
remarks: Documented in the Indian Jātaka (No. 389).

title: The Hare Promises to Dance
description: The hare says he will dance when the gate is opened. He escapes [K571.1]. Cf. Type 226.

title: Half of the Money Thrown into Water
description: A man makes money by selling milk (wine) mixed with water. A monkey throws the man’s money alternately into water and on land (ship) because the man sold half water and half milk [J1551.9].
remarks: Early European literary sources, see Cento novelle antiche (No. 97) and Dialogus creaturarum (No. 99).

title: The Nightcap Dealer and the Monkeys
description: A man who sells nightcaps puts one on and lies down to sleep. Some monkeys steal some of his caps and put them on. When the man wakes up and sees that the monkeys have his nightcaps, he takes his off and throws it in anger down on the ground. The monkeys copy him, so he gets his nightcaps back [B786].
remarks: Early literary version, see Hans Sachs, Der kremer mit den affen (1555).

title: The Monkey and the Nut
description: A monkey throws a nut away because it has a bitter shell, and overlooks the edible kernel [J369.2].

title: The Dogs’ Certificate (previously The Dog’s Certificate)
description: The dogs have a certificate which they give to a cat to keep it for them. A mouse destroys this certificate. Since then dogs and cats are enemies [A2281.1], also cats and mice [A2494.1.1].

literature.Hungarian: MNK I, No. 200, cf. No. 2001*, Dömötör 2001, 287
literature.Argentine: Chertudi 1960f. II, No. 22, Vidal de Battini 1980ff., Nos. 788–796

remarks: Documented in the 14th and 15th century by Klaret, Exemplarius (No. 116). The certificate’s content is often not described. 200, 200A and 200B are not clearly differentiated. Popular as a proverbial phrase.

title: The Dog Loses a Certificate (previously Dog Loses his Patent Right) which he had put under his tail to cross a river
description: The certificate guaran teed the dogs a privilege. To search for this lost certificate, dogs look (sniff) under each other ’s tails [A2275.5.5, cf. A2471.1]. Cf. Types 200, 200B.

literature.German: Ranke 1966, No. 8, Kooi/Schuster 1994, No. 246b, cf. No. 247, Hubrich-Messow 2000, No. 200, Berger 2001

remarks: Documented in 1530 in a German broadsheet. The specific privilege varies and often is not described. See Type 200.

title: Why Dogs Sniff at One Another
description: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Animals arrange a banquet and discover that the pepper is missing. One dog is sent to buy some but he does not return. Since then dogs sniff at one another to find that dog. Or, a dog is sent to get some medicine and does not return. (2) Some dogs are sent to heaven for an audience and, while waiting, they shit in heaven and are ch ased away. The next time spices or perfume are attached under their tails, but again they are chased away. These dogs do not return to the other dogs, who continue to look for the missing dogs by sniffing under each other ’s tails [A2232.8, Q433.3]. Cf. Type 200A.
remarks: (1) documented in the 19th century, (2) originates in an Aesopic fable (Phaedrus/Perry 1965, IV,19). See Type 200.

title: Enmity between the Hare and the Dog (previously Hare and Hunting Dog Conduct a Store )
description: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The hare (stag) borrows the shoes of the dog (hare) and runs away with them. Since then the dog chases the hare [Cf. A2494.4.4]. (2) The hare secretly shaves the fur off the dog’s soles. (Pre viously Type 119A*.)

title: Why Cat is Indoors and Dog Outside in Cold
description: A dog envies a cat her place indoors. They have a race and the winner gets to live indoors. The dog is faster than the cat, but loses because during the race he is attacked and detained by a beggar. Cf. Type 230*.

title: The Lean Dog Prefers Liberty to Abundant Food and a Chain
description: A lean dog (wolf, lion, donkey, goldfinch, butterfly) would rather be free than have abundant food and be chained [L451.2, L451.3, J212.1, cf. J211]. Cf. Type 1871Z(2).

literature.German: Joco-Seria (1631) No. 138, Gerlach, Eutrapeliarum I (1656) 16 No. 87, Vademecum III (1786) 108ff. (EM archive), Tomkowiak 1993, 231

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 485 No. 346, cf. 484f. No. 342).

title: The Dog Barks at the Thieves
description: A thief tries to feed a watchdog to stop his barking. The dog realizes it and continues to bark to chase the thief away. If his master is robbed, there will be nothing left for the dog [K2062, cf. B325.1].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 496f. No. 403).

title: Hostile Dogs are Made Friendly
description: They unite against a common enemy (wolf) [J145].
remarks: Narrated in the Babylonian Talmud ( Sanhedrin 105a) referring to the Old Testament (Num. 22,7).

title: The Dog at the Banquet
description: A dog is invited to dinner by another dog but is chased off by the cook. On his way home he meets a dog who asks him how the dinner was. The first dog claims that he was so drunk that he cannot remember anything [J874].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 483 No. 328).

title: The Two Stubborn Goats
description: Two goats (horse and donkey, lion and fox) meet each other on a small bridge (stone). Neither will step aside. Both go ahead (fight with each other) and fall into the water [W167.1, J133.1].
remarks: Documented by Pliny, Naturalis historia (VIII,201). For variants with stubborn men, see Type 1563*.

title: Sheep and Horse Have Eating Contest
description: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A sheep and a horse have an eating contest. The sheep thinks he lost because his legs were too weak [J2228]. (2) In the contest between goat and hare the goat wins because it ruminates.

title: Animals in Peril at Sea (previously Duck, Rooster, and Sheep in Peril at Sea)
description: When some animals (e.g. duck, rooster, sheep, goose, pig, goat, cat, mouse, rat) are in danger at sea the duck swims, the rooster flies up the mast, and the sheep drowns. Each animal calls out something that corresponds onomatopoetically to its charac teristic voice [J1711.1, A2426]. Cf. Types 106, 211B*, 236*, 289.
remarks: Tale explaining the meaning of animal voices (sometimes lost in translation).

title: Straw Threshed a Second Time
description: At night, the animals say they have good food because the straw has not been well threshed. The mas ter hears this and threshes the straw a second time. The animals go hungry [cf. J2362].

title: Rebellion of the Work Animals
description: A rooster advises a donkey and an ox to feign illness so they can work less. The farmer overhears this talk and has the rooster slaughtered [K1633]. Cf. Types 207A, 207B.

title: A Donkey Induces Overworked Ox to Feign Sickness
description: The donkey must do the ox’s work, so he persuades the ox to stop being ill. Cf. Types 207, 207B.
remarks: Documented in the Arabian Nights (Littmann 1921ff. I, 27–31).

title: Hard-hearted Horse and Donkey
description: A horse refuses to help an over burdened donkey, so it collapses. Afterwards, the horse has to carry the load alone [W155.1]. Cf. Types 207, 207A.
remarks: Aesopic fable of Babrios (Babrius/Perry 1965, No. 7), cf. also Plutarch, De tuenda sanitate praecepta (ch. 25).

title: Animals Ring Bell and Demand Justice
description: A king (Charlemagne, Anuširwān) has a bell which petitioners for justice may ring. An old horse (donkey) rings the bell and accuses his master of having chased him away because he is old and weak. The king orders the master to care for the old animal. Or, the bell is rung by a snake which is menaced by a toad. The king kills the toad and the snake shows gratitude by healing the blind king [B271.3].
remarks: Documented in the 15th century. Appears as a fable as well as in ser mons.

title: The Donkeys Decide to Kill the Saddler
description: Some donkeys decide to kill the saddler to get rid of their work. When an old donkey warns them that the next saddler will be inexperienced, they renounce their plan [Cf. J215].

title: Rooster, Hen, Duck, Pin, and Needle on a Journey [B296, F1025]
description: The animals and objects (also egg, millstone, dog, mouse, crayfish) hide in various parts of a house. They kill the house’s owner with their characteristic strengths [K1161]. In some variants they save him (a young woman) from danger or take revenge for one of their companions who was killed.

literature.German: Tomkowiak 1993, 242, Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 I, Nos. 10, 41, Hubrich-Messow 2000, Berger 2001
literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 34, Thompson/Roberts 1960, Jason 1989, Blackburn 2001, No. 29

title: Verlioka
description: The terrible demon, Verlioka, kills two girls and their grandmother. The grandfather sets out for the demon’s hut to pun ish him. On the way he meets various objects and animals (e.g. rope, cowdung, stick, duck, crayfish, acorn) which join him since they also want to take revenge. Together they kill the demon.

literature.Russian: SUS 210*B, Afanas’ev/Barag et al. 1984f. III, No. 301

remarks: Mainly documented in Russia.

title: The Two Donkeys and Their Loads (previously The Two Asses )
description: A donkey loaded with salt falls into a river. His load becomes light. A second donkey loaded with sponges (feathers) tries to reduce the weight in the same way, but he (almost) drowns, because the water makes his load heavier [J1612]. Or, two birds have a contest to see which of them can fly higher while carrying a load. One bird carries cotton, the other salt. During the contest it rains, so the second bird wins [K25.2].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 455 No. 180). Older variants have only one donkey with two different loads.

title: Animals Go into a Tavern (previously The Gander, the Drake, and the Boar Go into the Tavern )
description: Three animals go into a tavern. The first animal (gander, duck) orders a beer, the second (drake, goat) says they cannot pay for it, but the third (boar, turkey) reassures the innkeeper that they will pay later. Conversation between animals with imitation of animal voices. Cf. Types 106, 204, 236*.

title: The Lying Goat
description: A man sends the members of his family one after the other to pasture the goat. Back home, the goat always complains it did not get anything to eat. The man angrily sends away his sons (daughters, wife) or kills them. When he himself pastures the goat he realizes that it lies. He skins the goat (shaves its head) to punish it. The goat escapes into a foxhole and drives away a fox, a wolf and a bear. A bee (hedgehog, ant) succeeds in driving the goat away [K1151, Q488.1].

literature.German: Ranke 1966, No. 9, Tomkowiak 1993, 242, Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 I, No. 36, Hubrich-Messow 2000

remarks: Combination with Type 563 only in variants derived from Grimms’ Kinderund Hausmärchen (No. 36). The second part of the tale is often classified as Type 2015.

title: The Donkey Tries to Caress His Master (previously Ass Tries to Caress his Master like a Dog)
description: A donkey, watching how well the dog is treated, tries to flatter his master in the same way. But he is punished for his actions [J2413.1].

literature.Spanish: Childers 1977, No. J2413.1, Chevalier 1983, No. 21, Goldberg 1998, No. J2413.1
cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. H. 93, M. 45, S

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 438f. No. 91).

title: Singing Donkey and Dancing Camel (previously Camel and Ass Together Captured because of Ass’s Singing)
description: A donkey and a camel (fox and donkey, scorpion and frog) are captured because of the donkey’s singing. They have to work in a caravan. When the donkey refuses to cross a river with the caravan the camel has to carry it. The camel starts to dance and throws the donkey into the river [J2137.6, J2133.1]. Cf. Type 100.

cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, No. S. 40, cf. No. M

remarks: Documented in the early 12th century as an Arabian anecdote.

title: The Donkey in Lion’s Skin (previously Ass in Lion’s Skin Unmasked when he Raises his Voice)
description: A donkey (hare), disguised in a lion’s skin, spreads fear, but is found out by its voice or another charac teristic feature [J951.1, K362.5]. Cf. Type 123B.

cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. H. 272, H. 286, M. 151, not-H

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 486 No. 357).

title: A Jackdaw (Crow) Tries to Carry Off a Lamb as an Eagle Does
description: The lamb is too heavy but the jackdaw cannot drop it because it is caught in the lamb’s fleece [J2413.3].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 422 No. 2).

title: The Cat with the Candle (previously The Cat and the Candle)
description: (Includ ing the previous Type 217*.) A man trains a cat (monkey, dog) to hold lighted candles on its head [cf. K264.2]. When a mouse runs through the room, the cat drops the candle and chases the mouse [J1908.1]. Cf. Type 218.

literature.Algerian: Frobenius 1921ff. III, No. 50, Nowak 1969, No. 165, El-Shamy 2004

remarks: Documented in the 10th century in the Arabian literature (Basset 1924ff. II, 449 No. 127). Often part of a wager or a dispute about whether nature or education exert the greatest influence. Dispute between well-known charac ters (e.g. Solomon and Marcolf).

title: See Type 217.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: A Cat Transformed to a Maiden Runs after a Mouse
description: A cat (weasel) is transformed into a woman so she can marry a young man, but she continues to chase mice [J1908.2]. Cf. Type 217.
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 429 No. 50).

title: The Old Man Has a Rooster, the Old Woman a Hen
description: An old man envies a woman because of the eggs of her hen. He sends his rooster off to bring him some money. When the rooster returns with a lot of money, the old woman sends the hen off to do the same, but she returns without success.

title: The Hen that Laid the Golden Eggs
description: A hen (goose) lays one golden egg every day (for a poor woman). Thinking that the hen must be full of gold, the woman (her husband) kills it but finds nothing special inside [D876, J514, J2129.3].

literature.German: Sobel 1958, 25f., Rehermann 1977, 324 No. 18, Brunner/Wachinger 1986ff. IX, No. 2S/785, XIII, No. 2Wat/233

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 437 No. 87). Popular as a proverbial phrase .

title: The Dog and the Sow Argue (previously Dog and Hog Dispute )
description: A dog and a hog argue about which one of them gives birth more easi ly. When the dog declares that, of all animals, she gives birth the most easily, the hog points out that the dog’s pups are blind at birth [J243.1].

cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. not-H. 247, H. 251, M

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 465 No. 223).

title: The Rooster and the Pearl
description: A rooster prefers a single seed to a lot of pearls [J1061.1].

literature.Bulgarian: BFP, No. *245B*.  OTHER ANIMALS AND OBJECTS 220–299

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 521 No. 503).

title: The Council of Birds
description: The eagle as judge assigns to each species of birds their nesting places and work [B238.1].
remarks: Combined with etiological tales about birds’ habits. Documented in the late Middle Ages by Johannes Gobi Junior, Scala coeli (No. 327) and by Chaucer, The Parlement of Foules.

title: The Trial of the Crow by the Eagle
description: A crow is tried and punished for various crimes. In order to avenge itself, the crow slanders other birds who are then also punished.

title: The Election of King of Birds
description: The birds have a contest to choose their king [B236.0.1]. The wren wins by cleverness and becomes king [B242.1.2] [B236.1]. See esp. Types 221A and 221B.

cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. H. 244, M. 142, not-H. 57, cf. No. M. 344

remarks: This type comprises in its entirety 221A, 221B and motif A2233.3. Documented by Plutarch, Moralia (V,1) and Praecepta gerendae rei publicae (XII, 806E).

title: Test: Who Can Fly Highest? The birds agree that whichever of them flies highest will be their king
description: The wren hides in the eagle’s wings and waits until the eagle reaches his highest point. Then the wren flies out, higher than the eagle [K25.1]. Cf. Type 221.

literature.German: Tomkowiak 1993, 232f., Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 III, No. 171, Berger 2001

remarks: See Type 221.

title: Test: Who Can Go Deepest in Earth? The birds agree that whichever of them can go deepest in the earth will be their king
description: The wren goes down into a mousehole. The other birds try to starve him out [K17. 1.1]. The owl is supposed to guard the exit of the hole, but the wren escapes nevertheless [A2233.3]. Cf. Type 221.
remarks: Rarely independently transmitted. The etiological legend is sometimes used to explain why other birds chase the owl or why the owl is active only at night.

title: War between Birds (Insects) and Quadrupeds (previously War of Birds and Quadrupeds )
description: A bear (wolf, lion) insults the children of a wren (insults an insect). The wren declares war, and the flying animals fight against the quadrupeds. The fox leads the quadrupeds and lifts his tail to signal that they are on the advance. Gnats bite the fox under the tail, so he lowers it. The quadrupeds think they have lost and retreat [K2323.1]. The flying animals win [B261]. Cf. Type 103.

literature.German: Tomkowiak 1993, 242f., Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 II, No. 102, HubrichMessow 2000, Berger 2001
cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. H. 150, not-H. 302, cf. No. M. 265

remarks: Documented by Marie de France, Ésope (No. 65) in the 12th century. The modern tradition begins with J. and W. Grimm, Kinderund Hausmärchen (No. 102). The variants differ with regard to the cause of the war.

title: The Bat in War between Birds and Quadrupeds (previously Bat in War of Birds and Quadrupeds )
description: Because of its ambiguous form the bat joins first one side and then the other, but it always takes the side of the winner. The animals notice this when they make peace. Consequently, the bat is despised by all animals [B261.1]. Often used to explain why bats fly only at night [A2491.1].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 527 No. 566).

title: Quarrel between Mouse and Sparrow (previously War between Mouse and Sparrow)
description: (Including the previous Type 222B*.) A mouse and a sparrow want to share the food they have stored for the winter (try to divide a single remaining grain). Their quarrel turns into a war between birds and quadrupeds in which the eagle is injured.
remarks: Usually exists in combination with other types.

title: See Type 222B.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Bird and the Jackal (previously The Bird and the Jackal as Friends )
description: (Including the previous Types 56B*, 56C*, 56E*, and 248A*.) A jackal (fox) orders a bird (often a lark) to obtain food. The bird flies near men carrying baskets of food. The men drop the baskets to pursue the bird and the jackal eats the food. The jackal orders the bird to make him laugh. The bird lands on the heads of two men so that they fight with one another [K1082.3]. The jackal orders the bird to make him cry. The bird leads men or dogs to the jackals’s hiding place. The jackal orders the bird to save his life. The bird lures the jackal to a crocodile, then strikes the crocodile so that the jackal is able to escape. Cf. Type 248.

literature.German: Bechstein/Uther 1997 I, No. 48, Neumann 1971, No. 51, cf. Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 I, No. 58

remarks: Variants often contain only the first two or three episodes. These episodes may be motivated by enmity (the jackal killed the young birds) as well as by friendship. The previous Types 56B*, 56C* and 56E* include different combinations of two or three of the above episodes.

title: Bird (Beetle) Wedding (previously Wedding of the Turkey and the Pea cock)
description: Miscellaneous type. Birds (turtle and peacock, frog and mouse, owl and hoopoo, lark and nightingale, etc.) or insects (beetle, grasshopper, ant, etc.) intend to marry. Many guests (birds, insects, other animals) are invited and/or they are assigned to prepare for the wedding. The course of the wedding feast is describ ed (includ ing unpleasant event) [B282ff.]. Cf. Type 243*.

literature.German: Wacker nagel 1843, 37ff., Wossidlo 1897ff. II,1, 426–430, Röhrich/Brednich 1965f. II, No. 73, Bred nich 1979, 41f.

remarks: Documented in the 16th century. Popular as animal wedding song.

title: See Type 244.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Crane Teaches the Fox to Fly
description: A fox (jackal, wolf, tortoise) asks crane (stork) to teach him to fly. Once high up in the sky, the bird drops the fox [K1041]. Usually, the fox dies upon hitting the ground, but in some cases he is saved. Cf. Type 225A.

literature.Portuguese: Vasconcellos/Soromenho et al. 1963f. I, Nos. 6, 9, 11, 15, Cardigos (forthcoming)
literature.South African: Coetzee et al. 1967, No. 225, cf. No. J 2357.1.

title: The Tortoise Lets Itself be Carried by Birds (previously Tortoise Lets self be Carried by Eagle)
description: A tortoise is carried up into the air by two birds (herons, geese, swans) who hold onto a stick which the tortoise holds in its mouth. When it speaks, it loses its grip and drops to its death [J2357]. Or, a bird (eagle) takes the tortoise into the air, drops it so that it smashes, and eats it [J657.2, A2214.5.1]. Sometimes used to explain why the shell of the tortoise has cracks.

literature.South African: Coetzee et al. 1967, Nos. J2357, J 2357.1.

remarks: The first tale is of Buddhistic origin, the second is an Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 466 No. 230, 521 No. 490).

title: The Goose Teaches the Fox to Swim
description: The goose drowns it [K1042]. In some (German) variants, the goose teaches the fox to dance and flies away.

title: Geese Ask for Respite for Prayer
description: A fox (wolf) wants to eat geese (ducks, piglets) but they ask him to grant them a last wish: a prayer [K551.1] or a dance. They crackle continuously. Sometimes people come to help them (they are able to escape). Cf. Types 6, 1199.

literature.German: Haltrich 1956, No. 114, Uther 1990a, No. 38, Tomkowiak 1993, 243, Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 II, No. 86

title: The Crow and the Crayfish (previously The Crayfish Entices the Crow into Talking)
description: A crow catches a crayfish. The crayfish compli ments the crow, who opens its beak to reply. The crayfish falls into the water and escapes. Cf. Types 6, 6*, 57, and 61.

title: A Little Bird Tries to be Bigger (previously The Titmouse Tries to be as Big as a Bear)
description: A titmouse (wren) ruffles up her feathers to be as big as a bear but her children laugh at her. In her usual shape (sometimes also gnat, bee) she flies into the bear ’s (tiger, wolf) ear and kills him [L315.1]. Cf. Type 277A.

title: Animals Fear a Bird’s Body Part (previously The Hawk Frightened at the Snipe’s Bill)
description: A hawk is afraid of a snipe’s bill, but is reassured by the snipe [J2616]. Other animals fear the rooster (a fox fears a bell) because they believe that it has fire on its head. One animal tells them that it is harm less. Cf. Type 112**.
remarks: Variants with rooster originate in East Africa.

title: The Rearing of the Large-headed and Large-eyed Bird
description: An eagle (hawk) fosters an owl. When he learns how long the owl can live, he kills it [K1985].

title: The Race of the Rooster, the Birch-Cock and the Birch-Hen
description: The ani mals decide whichever wins a race may live in town (on the farm). The rooster deceives the others and wins [A2250.1]. Cf. Type 200D*.

title: See Type 231*.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Heron and the Fish (previously The Heron [Crane] Transports the Fish )
description: A heron (crane) tells the fish that their lake is drying up. It promises to transport them one by one to another lake, but eats them instead. A crab sees through the deception, seizes the heron by the throat, and kills it [J657.3, K815.14].
remarks: Documented in the Indian Jātaka (No. 38).

title: Animals Eat Each Other
description: (Including the previous Type 230B*.) This miscellaneous type consists of various tales in which smaller animals are eaten by bigger ones. Sometimes the last one in the food chain (fox, lion, bear) is shot by a hunter or bursts. Cf. Type 20A.

title: The Falcon and the Doves (previously The Eagle Wants to Tear the Dove to Pieces)
description: Doves beg a falcon to help them (they elect him king) but he eats them and their young [K815.8].

cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. M. 322, not-H. 172, cf. No. M

remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 520 No. 486).

title: The Birch-Cock and the Birds of Passage
description: A heathcock prefers to remain at home in spite of the hard winter than to go to foreign lands [J215.3].

title: Which Bird is Father? A very small bird goes to God with his adult son, and asks God to guess which of them is the father and which the son
description: God: “There is a spot on the father ’s nose”. The father quickly rubs his nose and God knows the answer [Cf. J1141.1].
remarks: Estonian variants have human actors.

title: A Crow Drops Pebbles into a Water Jug (previously Crow Drops Pebbles into Water Jug so as to be Able to Drink )
description: A thirsty crow drops pebbles into a tall jug of water. The water level rises so that the crow is able to drink from the jug [J101].
remarks: Documented by Plutarch, Moralia (No. 967A), also Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 493f. No. 390).

title: The Birds Escape by Shamming Death
description: Birds caught in a fowler ’s net (cage) follow the advice of an old bird and pretend to be dead. After the fowler throws them out onto the ground, they fly away [K522.4]. Cf. Types 1, 33, and 239.

title: The Birds Fly Off with the Net
description: Birds caught in a fowler ’s net fly off with the net [K581.4.1]. They fly to a mouse (rat) who gnaws the net and sets them free. Cf. Types 75, 75A.

literature.Indian: Bødker 1957a, No. 735, cf. Nos. 700, 1056, Thompson/Roberts 1960, Jason 1989

title: The Swallow and the Hemp-Seeds
description: Birds ignore the advice of a swallow (owl, tortoise) to eat hempseeds (mistletoe) as fast as they are sowed. Ridiculed, the swallow builds his nest among the dwellings of men. Later the other birds are caught in nets made from the hemp [J621.1]. Sometimes used to explain why the swallow lives close to humans .
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 428 No. 39).

title: The Birds and the Fowler
description: Birds see the watery eyes of a hunter (from cold) and think he weeps out of pity for them. One clever bird tells them that it is not so [J869.1].
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 531f. No. 576).

title: The Nightingale and the Blindworm
description: Both have one eye. The nightin gale (crow, dove, fox, tick) borrows the blindworm’s eye and then refuses to return it. Since then, she has two eyes and the blindworm has none. The latter lives in a tree where the nightingale has her nest and in revenge bores holes in the nightingale’s eggs [A2241.5]. Cf. Types 235, 244.
remarks: Documented in 1612 in a Polish variant. Also appears in 1812 in the first edition of the Kinderund Hausmärchen of J. and W. Grimm (No. 6), taken from a French source.

title: The Birds Brew Beer
description: Birds brew beer in a river with one grain or one ear of grain. They rejoice that the beer is excellent.
remarks: For variants with human actors see Type 1260A.

title: The Jay Borrows the Cuckoo’s Skin
description: But he does not return it [A2313.1, A2241].

title: See Type 2021.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: A Bird Has New Clothes Made
description: It flies away without paying [K233.1].

title: The Magpie Teaches the Dove to Build a Nest (previously The Thrush Teaches the Doves (etc
description: ) to Build Small Nests ). A dove (mag pie, sparrow) asks a magpie (thrush, swallow, crow) to show her how to build a nest. As soon as the magpie starts, the dove says “I know”, and persists in building her nest as before, so that the eggs nearly drop out [A2271.1]. In some variants the dove promises to give her cow to the mag pie and then regrets losing the cow. (Imitation of bird sounds.)

title: Miscellaneous Tales with Imitation of Bird Sounds
description: Cf. Types 106, 204. Some variants explain the sounds made by bittern [A1965.2] and hoopoe [A1952]. Two herdsmen send their cows to the wrong pasture. The hoopoe and the bittern tell them that one pasture is too rich, and another pasture too poor. (Imitation of bird sounds.)

literature.German: Bechstein/Uther 1997 II, No. 23, Kooi/Schuster 1994, No. 254, cf. No. 253, Grimm KHM/Uther 1996 III, No. 173, Hubrich-Messow 2000, 215

title: The Talking Parrot (previously Magpie Tells why Sow is Muddy )
description: A parrot (in early variants a magpie) gives wrong orders or makes inappropriate remarks and is punished by its master (thrown in the mud, loses the feathers on its head or is chased and hides under the stove). There the parrot meets an animal (sow, cat) or bald person and says, “You too must have had a quarrel with your master”. [J2211.2].

literature.Dutch: Sinninghe 1943, Nos. 218*, 237, Meder/Bakker 2001, No. 255, Kooi 2003, Nos. 108a, 108b

remarks: Documented in the 16th century.

title: The Dove and the Frog Boast to Each Other (previously The Keen Sight of the Dove and the Keen Hearing of the Frog)
description: A dove (falcon, crow) claims to have keen sight, and a frog (bee) believes it hears everything. They demonstrate their abilities to each other [K85, K86].

title: The Crow Helps the Deer Escape from the Snare
description: A deer helps a jackal, but when the deer is caught in a snare the jackal refuses to help him. On the advice of a crow the deer feigns death. When the hunter releases him, he bounds away [K642.1]. Cf. Types 1, 33, 105*, and 233A.

title: The Dove Trades Her Eggs (previously The Dove’s Egg-substitution)
description: (Including the previous Type 240*.) A magpie (crow, hen) persuades a dove to exchange eggs (in English variants to exchange nests): the dove gets the two eggs of the magpie for her seven. Since then the dove lays only two eggs and mourns the loss of the other eggs [A2247.4]. (Imitation of bird sounds.) In some variants a dove and a hen have a race for the eggs. The hen deceives the dove and wins. Cf. Type 230*.

title: See Type 240.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Bee Falls into the Water
description: A dove saves a bee (ant) from drown ing. When a hunter wants to shoot the dove, the bee stings the hunt er [B362, B457.1, B481.1]. Cf. Type 75.
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 468 No. 235).

title: The Officious Bird and the Monkey
description: A bird, sitting in its nest during a cold rain, asks a shivering monkey why it doesn’t build a house since it has hands like a man. The enraged monkey destroys the bird’s nest [B275.4, L462, Q295].
remarks: Documented in the Hitopadeśa (III,1).

title: The Crow’s Oath (previously The Frog Enticed out of his Hole )
description: A crow (another bird) entices a frog (toad) out of his hole and swears not to eat him. The crow breaks his oath [K815].
remarks: In Finland, also used as proverbial phrase.

title: See Type 1422.
description: Combined with another type as per title.

title: The Rooster Who Crows about Mistress’s Adultery Killed
description: The first rooster crows about the adultery committed by the mistress. He is killed. The second rooster crows about the first rooster being killed for telling the truth. He is also slaughtered. The third rooster is discreet and is allowed to live [J551.1]. Cf. Type 51A.
remarks: Documented in the Middle Ages by Étienne de Bourbon (No. 465) and Gesta Romanorum (No. 68).

title: The Raven in Borrowed Feathers
description: (Including the previous Type 224*.) A raven puts on swan (peacock) feathers. Other birds take them from him and leave him disgraced in the cold [J951.2, cf. J1062.1]. Sometimes a crow borrows feathers from other birds for his wedding day. (Previously Type 224*.)
remarks: Aesopic fable (Perry 1965, 441 No. 101). Popular as a proverbial phrase .

literature.Portuguese: Vasconcellos/Soromenho et al. 1963f. I, No. 74, Cardigos (forth com ing)
literature.German: Zincgref/Weidner IV (1655) 485f., Kobolt, Scherz und Ernst (1747) 572f., Vademecum III (1786) No. 140 (EM archive), Tomkowiak 1993, 266f.
cf: Adrados 1999ff. III, Nos. H. 103, M. 180, not-H. 77

title: See Type 1927.
description: Combined with another type as per title.
